title: hddtools: Hydrological Data Discovery Tools
text: Koppen Climate Classification widely used system classifying world’s climates. categories based annual monthly averages temperature precipitation. first updated Rudolf Geiger 1961, Kottek et al. (2006), Peel et al. (2007) Rubel et al. (2010). package hddtools contains function identify updated Koppen-Greiger climate zone, given bounding box.
code: # Define a bounding box areaBox <- terra::ext(-10, 5, 48, 62)  # Extract climate zones from Peel's map: KGClimateClass(areaBox = areaBox, updatedBy = "Peel") #>   ID Class Frequency #> 1  9   Csb         1 #> 2 15   Cfb      6199 #> 3 16   Cfc        10 #> 4 27   Dfc         3 #> 5 29    ET         1 # Extract climate zones from Kottek's map: KGClimateClass(areaBox = areaBox, updatedBy = "Kottek") #>   ID Class Frequency #> 1 32   Cfb     12301 #> 2 33   Cfc       507

title: hddtools: Hydrological Data Discovery Tools
text: Global Runoff Data Centre (GRDC) international archive hosted Federal Institute Hydrology Koblenz, Germany. Centre operates auspices World Meteorological Organisation retains services datasets major rivers world. Catalogue, kml files product Long-Term Mean Monthly Discharges open data accessible via hddtools. Information GRDC stations can retrieved using function catalogueGRDC input arguments, examle : advisable use package dplyr convenient filtering, examples provided . GRDC catalogue (subset) can used create map.
code: # GRDC full catalogue GRDC_catalogue <- catalogueGRDC() # Filter GRDC catalogue based on a country code GRDC_catalogue %>%   filter(country == "IT")  # Filter GRDC catalogue based on rivername GRDC_catalogue %>%   filter(river == "PO, FIUME")  # Filter GRDC catalogue based on which daily data is available since 2000 GRDC_catalogue %>%   filter(d_start >= 2000)  # Filter the catalogue based on a geographical bounding box GRDC_catalogue %>%   filter(between(x = long, left = -10, right = 5),          between(x = lat, left = 48, right = 62))  # Combine filtering criteria GRDC_catalogue %>%   filter(between(x = long, left = -10, right = 5),          between(x = lat, left = 48, right = 62),          d_start >= 2000,          area > 1000) # Visualise outlets on an interactive map library(leaflet) leaflet(data = GRDC_catalogue %>% dplyr::filter(river == "PO, FIUME")) %>%   addTiles() %>%  # Add default OpenStreetMap map tiles   addMarkers(~long, ~lat, popup = ~station)

title: hddtools: Hydrological Data Discovery Tools
text: MOPEX dataset contains river basin characteristics data hundreds river basins range climates US. catalogue can retrieved follows: station, historical hydrometeorological data can also retrieved.
code: # MOPEX full catalogue MOPEX_catalogue <- catalogueMOPEX()  # Extract data within a geographic bounding box MOPEX_catalogue %>%   filter(dplyr::between(x = Longitude, left = -95, right = -92),          dplyr::between(x = Latitude, left = 37, right = 41)) # Get stations with recondings in the period 1st Jan to 31st Dec 1995 MOPEX_catalogue %>%   filter(Date_start <= as.Date("1995-01-01"),          Date_end >= as.Date("1995-12-31"))  # Get only catchments within NC MOPEX_catalogue %>%   filter(State == "NC") # Take the first record in the catalogue river_metadata <- MOPEX_catalogue[1,]  # Get corresponding time series river_ts <- tsMOPEX(id = river_metadata$USGS_ID)  # Extract data between 1st Jan and 31st December 1948 river_ts_shorter <- window(river_ts,                            start = as.Date("1948-01-01"),                            end = as.Date("1948-12-31"))  # Plot plot(river_ts_shorter,      main = river_metadata$Name,      xlab = "",      ylab = c("P [mm/day]","E [mm/day]", "Q [mm/day]", "Tmax [C]","Tmin [C]"))

title: hddtools: Hydrological Data Discovery Tools
text: Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) manages river level data hundreds gauging stations UK. catalogue stations derived list : https://www2.sepa.org.uk/waterlevels/CSVs/SEPA_River_Levels_Web.csv. time series last days available SEPA website can downloaded using following function: Plese note data updated every 15 minutes code always generate different plots.
code: # SEPA catalogue SEPA_catalogue <- catalogueSEPA() # Take the first record in the catalogue Perth_metadata <- SEPA_catalogue[1,]  # Single time series extraction Perth_ts <- tsSEPA(id = Perth_metadata$LOCATION_CODE)  # Plot plot(Perth_ts,      main = Perth_metadata$STATION_NAME,      xlab = "",      ylab = "Water level [m]")  # Get only catchments with area above 4000 Km2 SEPA_catalogue %>%   filter(CATCHMENT_AREA >= 4000)  # Get only catchments within river Ayr SEPA_catalogue %>%   filter(RIVER_NAME == "Ayr") # Multiple time series extraction y <- tsSEPA(id = c("234253", "234174", "234305"))  plot(y[[1]], ylim = c(0, max(y[[1]], y[[2]], y[[3]])),       xlab = "", ylab = "Water level [m]") lines(y[[2]], col = "red") lines(y[[3]], col = "blue")

title: hddtools: Hydrological Data Discovery Tools — hddtools
text: Many governmental bodies institutions currently committed publish open data result trend increasing transparency, based wide variety information produced public expense now becoming open freely available improve public involvement process decision policy making. Discovery, access retrieval information , however, always simple task. Especially access data APIs allowed, downloading metadata catalogue, selecting information needed, requesting datasets, de-compression, conversion, manual filtering parsing can become rather tedious. R package hddtools open source project, designed make operations efficient means reusable functions. package facilitate access various online data sources : KGClimateClass (http://koeppen-geiger.vu-wien.ac./): Koppen Climate Classification map used classifying world's climates based annual monthly averages temperature precipitation GRDC (http://www.bafg.de/GRDC/EN/Home/homepage_node.html): Global Runoff Data Centre (GRDC) provides datasets major rivers world Data60UK (http://tdwg.catchment.org/datasets.html): Data60UK initiative collated datasets areal precipitation streamflow discharge across 61 gauging sites England Wales (UK). MOPEX (https://www.nws.noaa.gov/ohd/mopex/mo_datasets.htm): dataset contains historical hydrometeorological data river basin characteristics hundreds river basins US. SEPA (https://www2.sepa.org.uk/WaterLevels/): Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) provides river level data hundreds gauging stations UK. package complements R's growing functionality environmental web technologies bridging gap data providers data consumers. designed initial building block scientific workflows linking data models seamless fashion.
